p: Among the oil phenolics, p-HPEA-EDA and 3,4-DHPEA-EA have been shown drive the taste properties of VOO. We found that average content of p-HPEA-EDA (oleocanthal), which is likely to be the main phenolic responsible for VOO pungency ( Andrewes et al., 2003), was 25% lower ( P = 0.009) in the oils from D- V. dahliae infected trees, and it is likely there would be an associated lowered perception of pungency in these oils. Similarly, content of 3,4-DHPEA-EA, which may be a key compound for bitterness in VOO ( Mateos et al., 2004), was almost 20% lower ( P = 0.018) in oils of infected trees. Mateos et al. (2004) developed an equation that includes oil content of 3,4-DHPEA-EA to calculate VOO bitterness; according to this calculation, we estimated that average perception of bitterness was around 17% lower in oils obtained from infected trees.
